Award.AwardTitle: Transnational Networks Amid Global Crisis and Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1323130
PI: Jackie Smith
Co-PI: Melanie Hughes
University of Pittsburgh

In this proposal, investigators map populations of transnational organizations, including inter-governmental organizations (IGOs), international nongovernmental organizations (INGOs), and transnational social movement organizations (TSMOs) to document how changes in these populations impact state outcomes ranging from human rights practices to international trade and health policies. It is known that such wide-ranging impacts result from complex interactions among these diverse organizations, but existing research fails to account for network relations among different types of groups, for changes in the structure of inter-organizational relations over time, or for implications of such changes for models of world politics. This project uses network analysis to explore changes in network relations among IGOs, INGOs and TSMOs over the last thirty years. The investigators expect that recent financial crises and changes in the international political arena - such as the growth of China and other emerging economies, financial crises in the U.S. and Europe, and the global spread of popular protests - have altered the ways in which international nongovernmental and governmental organizations align with one another. A key contribution of this study will the production of new data, including: 1) an updated biennial dataset on the population of TSMOs (adding the years 2005-2013) and 2) a new Inter-Organizational Networks Database of INGO, TSMO, and IGO connections, constructed decennially from 1983 to 2013. A secondary goal of this study is to bridge data and research on INGOs and TSMOs, allowing world polity and social movement scholars to understand if, when, and how social-change orientations of organizations matter.

Broader Impact
The study advances understandings of global conflict and change, and therefore offers insights that can contribute to broader public and policy debates. The investigators will provide reports on the analyses that are accessible to general audiences in order to better inform public discourse about global conflicts and the various organizations and institutions addressing these matters. Specifically the research will speak to questions about how social movements relate to inter-governmental organizations, as both types of groups work to address conflict in areas of major global significance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated transnational organizations, how they connect to one another to form networks, and how these relationships have changed over the last thirty years. Our study included three different types of organizations: inter-governmental organizations (IGOs) like the United Nations, international nongovernmental organizations (INGOs) like the International Philatelic Association, and transnational social movement organizations (TSMOs) like Amnesty International.

            One key outcome of the project is the production of new data. The project updated an organizational database on TSMOs to include more recent years (2005 to 2013). These data cover the full population of TSMOs that exist in the world and provide information about these groups, including each organization’s aims, structure, and location in the world. These data should be of use to a wide range of researchers and practitioners who hope to understand groups that are crossing borders to work for social change. The project also resulted in a new Inter-Organizational Networks Database of INGO, TSMO, and IGO connections, constructed every ten years from 1983 to 2013. These data allow researchers to better understand how TSMOs are networking with other international organizations over time. The dataset includes information on who is connected to who, and information on the nature of the relationship (for example, one group finances the other). These data allow researchers and practitioners to study the changing behavior of transnational organizations in dynamic new ways.

            For academics, distinguishing transnational groups working towards social change from the larger population of international organizations was a challenging but important contribution of the project. Areas of activity that were once the sole purview of social movements – such as micro-finance and sustainable development – have been co-opted by organizations working to maintain the status quo. Identifying this pattern informs the study of organizational population change. Carefully classifying organizations also provides a substantive, empirically grounded foundation for the study of late 20th and early 21st century social conflicts operating at the global level. These data also bridge distinct academic research areas on TSMOs and INGOs, allowing scholars to better understand if, when, and how social-change orientations of organizations matter.

            Our study also helped reveal the ways that the population of social movement organizations is changing over time. First, we observe continuing growth in social-change oriented organizations operating in multiple countries. Second, we see evidence that the organizational structure of TSMOs are changing. Organizations are becoming more decentralized and are integrating a wider array of activists from the global South. Third, our results show changes in relations among transnational organizations. Transnational social movement organizations are reporting fewer ties to inter-governmental organizations (IGOs), and their ties with IGOs have become more decentralized. These patterns suggest that social change groups are looking outside of inter-governmental arenas to address persistent global problems such as inequality, gender and other forms of discrimination, poverty, and climate change.
